content.description: This is the left facing dihedral on the right side of the wall.  There aren't alot of short, quick climbs in Arches;...this is one of them.  It's fun; c'mon;...go do it.
content.protection: 1 through 4 cams.  Stoppers.  Just eye-ball the thing, and take the gear ya think you'll need;...it's a crack.
content.location: 1.8 miles up the winding road from the Arche's Visitor's Center.

content.description:
The route overhangs at the base and quickly widens, which makes the moves tricky since you can't quite get a hands-free rest to advance stacked jams.

This video should show you plenty :-)
content.protection:
A #5 and/or #6 C4 are nice to start. You might appreciate a VG 9 to protect you from a ground fall until you hit the easy part.

To get off, downclimb this side and French-free off the cams you placed. If you placed both a #5 & #6 C4, it is easy to work them down like jugging until you can touch the ground with your feet.
content.location:
This is the beautiful split boulder a few hundred feet left and downslope of Zippy Zebra, at:

38째37'15.0"N, 109째36'22.1"W

content.description:
The route overhangs at the base and quickly widens, which makes the moves tricky since you can't quite get a hands-free rest to advance stacked jams.

This video should show you plenty :-)
content.protection: A single #5 C4 protects the crux well (on a leash) and can be helpful as a backup or french-freeing option for the downclimb descent.
content.location:
This is the beautiful split boulder a few hundred feet left and downslope of Zippy Zebra, at:

38째37'15.0"N, 109째36'22.1"W

content.description: Hands to wide-crack/ramp shimmy to fingers in a right-facing corner. Crux is fingers near the top. Nice enough climbing, but the steeper part is pretty short. Worth doing if you're in the area for Zippy Zebra.
content.protection: 1-2 sets from blue metolius to #3 cam.
content.location: Portable Trash Unit is the first right-facing dihedral to the right of Zippy Zebra. Desert Rock mentions a walk off to the left, but there is also now a 2-piton rappel anchor. Bring webbing or chain.

climbs.name: The Dumpster
climbs.fa: Charlie Fowler, belayed by Eric Bjornstad (1986/10/13)

content.description:
The bottom begins as very soft and sandy boulders, but cleans up as soon as you start up the fist-sized crack behind a flake in the wall. Reach a wide pod to squeeze inside to place gear in better rock, then set off up great hand jams to another rest just beneath the final overhang. This is #0.75 Camalots in a great crack leading to a flaring and sandy fist crack, with some face features on the right to help for stemming.

The Bjornstad guidebook says the descent is a cl. 3 walkoff, but it is more like a 5.4 slab/face walkoff where you and your follower might appreciate a belay and piece just before and after the crux section.
content.protection: Friends: (2) #1 through #3, (1) #3.5 according to guidebook. With cam bumping, we did Camalots 1 x #0.5 through #3.
content.location: This is the next corner to the right of the Portable Trash Unit. Alternatively, this is the prominent right-facing dihedral (and first one) left of the end of the South-facing wall.
